s.text: He's never more winning than when he projects loserdom.

Think High Noon by way of Scorsese, with a touch of Peyton Place . (I could also cite Carl Franklin's One False Move and Tony Richardson's The Border --but the list of influences would run as long as this review.)

For most of Cop Land , we watch Stallone get bullied and stared down by everyone in the large cast, while we wait for him to awaken from his stupor and start blowing bad guys away--which you know he has to do or he would never have accepted the role.
"I look at you, sheriff," he says, "and I see a man who's waiting for something to do."
I use the word "loser" so casually because the film virtually brands it on his forehead.
Most striking is the camera placement.
Mangold and his cinematographer, Eric Alan Edwards, can't get enough of Garrison's terraced cliffs above the Hudson, and they rarely lose sight of the imposing Manhattan skyline.
Cop Land shares its leading man's slow-wittedness, but also his likability.
In Cop Land , Stallone plays Freddy Heflin, the loser sheriff of Garrison, N.J., just across the George Washington Bridge from Manhattan.
